content.title: Femoral Artery Aneurysm
content.summary: Femoral artery aneurysms are focal dilations of the common femoral artery exceeding 1.5 times normal diameter. They are the second most common peripheral aneurysm and frequently associated with popliteal and aortic aneurysms.
content.definition: Focal dilation of the femoral artery to greater than 1.5 times its normal diameter (>1.5-2cm)

epidemiology.prevalence: Second most common peripheral aneurysm (after popliteal)

classification.true_aneurysm: Involves all three arterial wall layers
classification.pseudoaneurysm: Contained rupture; often iatrogenic or anastomotic

surgical_repair.interposition_graft: Aneurysm excision with vein or prosthetic graft

pseudoaneurysm.surgery: If large, infected, or failed conservative treatment

content.statement: Femoral Artery Aneurysm is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Peripheral-Aneurysms that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Femoral Artery Aneurysm helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Femoral Artery Aneurysm include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Femoral Artery Aneurysm.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity

definition.@value: Focal dilation of femoral artery exceeding 1.5 times normal diameter

medicalCode.description: Aneurysm of artery of lower extremity

learning_objectives: Define femoral aneurysm and distinguish true from pseudo
clinical_pearls: 40-60% have popliteal; 50-85% have AAA - screen for both
Thrombin injection first-line for iatrogenic pseudoaneurysm

sources.source: UpToDate. (2024). Femoral Artery Aneurysm. Wolters Kluwer.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
